The purpose of the air conditioning system (A/C system) is to meet the cooling capacity needs of individual rooms. In order to optimize energy-saving in the A/C system, it is essential to conduct a study on the operational status of various equipment, considering the comfort demand of the human body and dynamic electricity prices. This feature will enable collaborative control of the A/C system. Consequently, this paper presents a two-stage operational optimization strategy. Firstly, the comfort requirement is taken into consideration, and the room's set temperature is treated as a decision variable. An optimization strategy is proposed to meet real-time electricity prices and indoor cooling demand. Furthermore, by optimizing the cooling demand, the operation of the main equipment in the A/C system is also optimized, leading to the derivation of an optimal cooling strategy at the minute level. According to this strategy, there are significant reductions in the energy consumption and the carbon emission relative to the rated operating conditions at each time period. The energy consumption can be reduced by up to 4.11%, and the carbon emission can be reduced by up to 30.81%. Keywords Public building Air conditioning system Time-delay characteristics Comfort requirement Two-stage optimization strategy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The building sector accounts for over 20 % of China's total energy consumption, with A/C systems being the primary energy-consumption equipment responsible for about 60 % of the total energy consumption in buildings. However, most A/C systems operate at lower efficiency. There are two main reasons causing this situation: one is that the A/C system is in partial load operation most of the time, and it is prone to a phenomenon of large flow and small temperature difference during operation. Subsequently, deviation from the designed working conditions leads to huge energy loss, the other one is, in terms of control, the operating parameters cannot be adjusted in time with change of load, the control system takes a long time to be stable when a disturbance occurs, making it difficult to achieve best energy-saving outcomes. Therefore, the research on the energy-saving optimization strategy of the A/C system in this paper aims to achieve the best comprehensive energy efficiency while meeting the comfort demand of the human body. This is of great significance for improving the green power resources of public buildings. emissions (¥/kg) ε ( t ) The dynamic carbon emission factor (¥/kg) Existing energy modeling researches are summarized in three categories: the physical model, the empirical model, and the data model. The physical model is essentially a more accurate mathematical formula model, but the model involves a large number of parameters to be determined, making it more complex and difficult to solve. Also, many researchers combine the physical model with engineering experience to further simplify the model and obtain a more practical empirical model. The data model is based on many machine learning methods and data mining theories. However, a large amount of operational data is required to approximate the unknown expression or complex function by increasing the model's complexity. Reference [1] developed a stochastic predictive control model for an A/C system to predict uncertain loads for each service area of the A/C system. The model establishes a probability density function, initializes it by using historical data, and updates it with new data at any time. In [2], a new direct load control model was proposed, which performed real-time scheduling of the A/C system with minimum disturbance error. In [3], the A/C system was detailed using grey box model system's identification and combined with building energy simulation software. The model was then linearized to obtain a linear time-invariant state space model. Reference [4] proposed a prediction model for the A/C system to satisfy the indoor comfort level. Reference [5] proposed a two-stage control model for the A/C system. The first stage model defined the variables of the cooling source and the air loop, while the second stage model focused on the fine-control adjustment of the fan. Also, the water loop power is used as the basis of model tracking, while the air loop can flexibly adjust the model parameters of the fan. A method for the A/C system using spatio-temporal data was proposed to predict the spatial distribution of indoor environmental parameters. The method involved a graph-based multi-source data integration, a graph neural network for indoor environment modeling, and a spatio-temporal model for online optimal control in [6]. Reference [7] established a thermo-electric model of the A/C system to describe the dynamic operation process of the subsystems' characteristics. It then discretized the thermo-electric operation characteristics of the A/C system while proposing a method for quantitatively assessing the A/C system regulation service. Reference [8] modeled the internal units of the A/C system by considering the participation of the A/C system in the auxiliary services of the power system. It reduced the load by flexibly controlling the water flow rate, air flow rate, and temperature within the system. In [9], a real-time optimal control strategy was proposed for the A/C system. The strategy was based on an adaptive regression model, which utilized a regression model to represent the relationship between power consumption and optimization variables of the A/C system. This approach improved the accuracy of the model and at the same time reduced the computational burden of model updating and optimization. Reference [10] modeled the components, such as fans and chillers, within a building's A/C system in detail. It used a control algorithm based on trading market to better facilitate demand response and ancillary services. The literatures above present a variety of modeling methods for the A/C system's energy consumption, which can be effectively used in the optimizing the energy consumption of the A/C system. While existing research methods have achieved the tracking control of the A/C system through time delay neural net-works [11], reinforcement learning, and other methods, they have also established the corresponding time lag model. However, models of the A/C system established in the above literature neglected the significant effect of users' comfort and the thermal delay on the operation of the A/C system. Reference [12] studied the application of fuzzy control algorithms to control the flow rate of cooling water and chilled water in the A/C system. The controlled variables included room temperature and relative humidity. The findings indicated that the fuzzy control effectively regulated the room temperature during part-load operation, and demonstrated greater energy efficiency compared to traditional proportional-integral-derivative control. Reference [13] proposed a reinforcement learning-based method to control a cooling system using building climate control data. The method was experimentally validated the method in the laboratory, demonstrating that it can achieve convergence within 20 days and obtain 90 % of the mathematically optimal solutions under different outdoor temperature scenarios. Reference [14] reviews studies published since 2000 that apply artificial neural networks to predict the usage and demand of building energy. In [15], a deep reinforcement learning algorithm was applied to optimize energy efficiency in inverter air conditioners. The algorithm was employed to analyze the relationship between the compressor output and the opening of the electronic expansion valve, revealing their significant impact on chiller's efficiency. Reference [16] explored the application of thermal storage technology for managing the load of A/C systems, including load transfer and deployment. The study utilized a multi-objective genetic algorithm to optimize the operation of different refrigerants in the vapor compression refrigeration cycle of the system. This system utilized a thermal energy storage system that consumes lower power compared to conventional A/C systems. Reference [17] proposed a method for predicting the energy-efficiency ratio of the A/C system using extreme learning machine. This method aimed to optimize and control the A/C system, considering high dimensionality and large amount of data associated with the A/C system. In [18], an energy-saving optimization control strategy based on maintaining a constant temperature difference of the chilled water's indoor unit was proposed to address the uneven distribution of chilled water temperature and the difference between the chilled water flow regulation method and the actual operation state in the A/C system. This strategy has been applied in engineering research and has effectively reduced the energy consumption of the A/C system, minimized the regulation time required to achieve stable indoor temperatures, and improves the environmental comfort level. Reference [19] proposed a model-free optimal control method for a centralized chiller using game theory and the reinforcement learning algorithm SARSA for agent coordination and learning, incorporating a multi-intelligence approach. A variable differential pressure reset method is proposed in [20], based on the adaptive adjustment algorithm of the Mamdani fuzzy model, to optimize the differential pressure set value of the chilled water system in the A/C system. This aimed to make the system operation more efficient. Reference [21] established an energy consumption model for the A/C system in the hotel according to the working principles of the chiller, chilled water pump and cooling tower. It also optimized the operation parameters of the water supply system at different load rates to derive the operation control strategy for each equipment. The operational optimization strategy mentioned in the above literature is based on a fixed temperature set point. These strategies do not consider reducing the initial demand for cooling load. Therefore, considering comfort and economy, this paper first attempts to establish an optimization strategy for air conditioning set temperatures, aiming to reduce cooling load demand by adjusting user air conditioning usage patterns. After analyzing the existing literature, this paper proposes a two-stage optimization process to obtain optimal values for energy consumption and carbon emissions. The first stage aims to adjust the mode of user air conditioning temperature settings to obtain the cold load demand and human comfort optimization values for different electricity price periods. The focus of the second stage is to reduce the energy consumption of air conditioning equipment to achieve energy saving and carbon reduction in the air conditioning system. The main contributions are as follow: 1) Based on the recursive least squares method, the parameters of the main energy-consuming equipment inside the A/C system are identified to improve the accuracy of units' energy consumption, which paves the way for optimizing the energy saving strategy of the A/C system. 2) In the first stage, an indoor cooling load's demand optimization model is established to obtain the indoor set temperature's reference value for each time period. In this model, weights are assigned to human comfort and time-sharing tariff information, while the impact of both the A/C system's time lag effect and different functional zones in the building are considered to further reduce the cooling demand for the indoor load. 3) In the second stage, an energy saving and carbon reduction optimization model is established to minimize the sum of the energy consumption cost and carbon emission cost. Both parameters' identification of the main energy-consuming equipment and optimization constraints of each time period in the first stage are considered as constraints in this model. 2 Energy consumption model of the A/C system This paper aims to optimize the energy consumption of the equipment's operation in the A/C system by establishing the energy consumption model of the main equipment of the A/C system. The parameters of the equipment are identified using the recursive least squares method. The typical A/C system in public buildings generally consists of an air adjustment system and a cold source system. The basic working principle is illustrated in Fig. 1 . The energy consumption of the air adjustment system constitutes approximately 25 % to 30 % of the overall energy usage of the A/C system. The chiller serves as the primary source of cooling during the summer months. It is integral to the cold source system and is the primary consumer of energy within the system, accounting for approximately 40 %-50 % of the total energy consumption. 2.1 Model of major energy consumption equipment 2.1.1 Energy consumption model of the chiller The chiller is responsible for the majority of energy consumption, highlighting the need to develop an energy consumption model that can accurately depict the correlation between cooling load and chiller power [22]. The paper establishes a model for the energy consumption of the chiller, taking into account factors such as cooling capacity, chiller load rate, chilled water supply temperature, and cooling water inlet temperature. (1) P chiller = W chiller ∙ P L R chiller where P chiller is the actual operating power of the chiller, W chiller indicates the operating power of the chiller under the rated working condition, PL R chiller represents partial load rate of the chiller. W chiller is determined by rated efficiency CO P nom of the unit and temperature coefficient Temp of circulating water: (2) W chiller = Q nom CO P nom · T e m p (3) Temp = b 0 + b 1 · T chws + b 2 · T chws 2 + b 3 · T cws + b 4 · T cws 2 + b 5 · T cws · T chws where Q nom indicates the rated cooling capacity of the chiller, T chws and T cws respectively represents supply temperature of the chilled water and supply temperature of the cooling water, b 0 , b 1 , b 2 , b 3 , b 4 , b 5 are temperature regression coefficients. The partial load rate PL R chiller of the chiller is as follows: (4) PL R chiller = a 0 + a 1 · Q chiller Q nom + a 2 · Q chiller Q nom 2 where Q chiller represents the actual cooling capacity of the cooling water unit, a 0 , a 1 , a 2 represent partial load correction factors. 2.1.2 Energy consumption model of variable frequency pump A variable frequency pump comprises a frequency converter, a motor, and a water pump, which plays a crucial role in supplying water to the A/C system [23]. In practical applications, the energy consumption of a pump is typically represented as: (5) P pump = P pump , n o m c 0 + c 1 · P L R pump + c 2 · P L R pump 2 + c 3 · P L R pump 3 (6) PL R pump = m chw m nom where P pump represents the actual power of the pump, P pump , n o m represents the rated power of the pump, m nom indicates the rated flow of the pump, m chw indicates the actual flow of the pump, c 0 , c 1 , c 2 , c 3 are polynomial fitting coefficients. 2.1.3 Energy consumption model of the cooling tower fan The energy consumption of cooling towers is very much related to the performance of fans [24]. The energy consumption of continuously variable speed fan can be modeled as: (7) P tfan = P tfan , n o m d 0 + d 1 · P L R tfan + d 2 · P L R tfan 2 + d 3 · P L R tfan 3 (8) PL R tfan = m atfan m atfan , n o m where P tfan represents the power of the cooling tower fan, P tfan , n o m stands for the rated power of the cooling tower fan, d 0 , d 1 , d 2 , d 3 are polynomial fitting coefficients, PL R tfan indicates load rate of the fan, m atfan represents the actual air volume of the fan, m atfan , n o m indicates the rated air volume of the fan. 2.1.4 Energy consumption model of the indoor fan The energy consumption of the indoor unit can be synthesized into a cubic function of air volume by referring to the model of the cooling tower fan: (9) P cfan = P cfan , n o m e 0 + e 1 · P L R cfan + e 2 · P L R cfan 2 + e 3 · P L R cfan 3 (10) PL R cfan = m acfan m acfan , n o m where P cfan , n o m represents the rated power of the fan, P cfan indicates the actual power of the fan, e 0 , e 1 , e 2 , e 3 are fitting coefficients of the polynomial model, PL R cfan is load ratio of the fan, m acfan , n o m stands the rated air volume of the fan, m acfan indicates the actual air volume of the fan. 2.2 Parameter identification of energy consumption model Recursive least square method is used to accommodate the fitting parameters to trend of data's variation, and its core iterative formulas are as follow [25]: (11) θ k = θ k - 1 + K k · y k - x T k · θ k - 1 K k = P k - 1 · x k 1 + x T k · P k - 1 · x k P k = 1 λ · I - K k · x T k · P k - 1 where θ k represents new identification parameter vector, θ k - 1 represents identification parameter vector of last recurrence, K k represents iterative error gain vector, y k represents output vector, x k represents input vector, P k represents iterative transition matrix, λ represents forgetting factor. a) Parameter identification of the chiller model. The linear equation corresponding to Eq. In the initial phase, a strategy is developed to optimize the temperature set value of the A/C system's end and the hourly indoor cooling load demand by integrating various tariff information and considering human comfort. In the subsequent phase, the cooling requirements for the indoor load are diminished through the incorporation of an intermediate moment control strategy, which is based on the optimization carried out in the initial phase. This approach aims to enhance energy conservation and reduce carbon emissions. 3.1 The first stage: Demand modeling of indoor cooling loads considering tariff and comfort weights 3.1.1 Objective function of indoor cooling loads model The minimum indoor cooling load's demand, which considers weight of time-of-use tariffs and the most widely applicable Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) index [26], is taken as the optimization objective. The objective function is set as follows: (17) min f = min ∑ t = t 1 t 2 ω 1 q sys ( t ) - q sys , m i n q sys , m a x - q sys , m i n + ω 2 P M V where ω 1 and ω 2 are weight coefficients, satisfying the relation, q sys , m a x represents maximum cooling load's demand, q sys , m i n represents minimum cooling load's demand, PMV indicates comfort value under the set temperature. The weight coefficients in the model are as follow: (18) ω 1 = k · p t · Δ P M V Δ q sys + Δ P M V (19) ω 2 = 1 - k · p t · Δ q sys Δ q sys + Δ P M V (20) Δ q sys = q sys ( T set , m a x ) - q sys ( T set , m i n ) (21) Δ P M V = P M V ( T set , m a x ) - P M V ( T set , m i n ) where k is fluctuation coefficient, p t represents the electricity price in t period, T set , m a x and T set , m i n indicate maximum and minimum set temperature, q sys ( T set , m a x ) and q sys ( T set , m i n ) respectively indicate the cooling load's demand at the set temperature, PMV ( T set , m a x ) and PMV ( T set , m i n ) respectively represent the human comfort value at its corresponding set temperature. The PMV in the model is as follows: (22) PMV = 0.119 e 16.654 - 4030.183 t a + 235 + 0.191 t a - 4.224 - 0.272 × 10 - 8 [ 0.499 t a + 289.97 4 - ( t a + 273 ) 4 ] The association between the indoor temperature set point t a and PMV is shown in Table 1 . In this paper, the range of PMV is set as −0.5 to 0.5 and PPD (Predicted Percentage of Dissatisfied) is 10 % according to ISO7730 [27]. 3.1.2 Constraint of indoor cooling loads model At present, indoor temperature set value is fixed during the operation of most the A/C systems, and the demand for cooling capacity needs to be adjusted. As an indoor control variable to reduce the cooling load, the energy consumption of the A/C system can be affected by adjusting the set temperature. Through theoretical analysis of building heat transfer process, the assumptions are as follow: a) Fluctuation process of outdoor temperature T 0 is regarded as a sine function, the angular frequency is ω , the average outdoor temperature is T ¯ 0 , and the period is 24 h. b) It is assumed that during working period of the A/C system, room air temperature T 1 at any period is equal to indoor temperature set value T set . Indoor temperature can reach a stable value within 1 h. c) Internal surface temperature of thermal insulation material outside building T s distributes evenly. d) During the operation of the A/C system, the outdoor solar heat radiation gain and the heat gain generated by indoor electrical equipment, etc. are viewed as a pooled heat source E, ignoring heat exchange process of the heat source during idle period of the A/C system. 1) Indoor heat balance: According to heat transfer of the room when the A/C system works in cooling mode and the assumptions made, the heat balance equations of the room during time period t 1 to t 2 are as follow [27]: (23) M C m ∂ T m ∂ t + A 0 h 0 T m - T 0 + A 0 h i T m - T i = 0 (24) q sys + A 0 h i T m - T i + E = 0 where M represents total mass of external thermal material, C m represents heat capacity of the thermal substance itself, T m means an average temperature of external wall, A 0 represents total area of the external heat storage material, h 0 represents convection coefficient of the external heat storage material and the room air, h i represents the coefficient of heat exchange between the thermal substance i and the room, q sys indicates required cooling capacity of the room, E represents total heat gain of the room. 2) Outdoor temperature changes: According to assumption (a), the outdoor temperature's change can be expressed as: (25) T 0 = T ¯ 0 + Δ T ¯ 0 sin ω t After inserting Eq. By analyzing the delay of load's change, the unit can be prepared for start-up in advance, so as to quickly meet needs of personnel comfort when load meets requirements. The time-lag phenomenon plays a positive role in energy saving of the system in this case. This paper considers impact of time-delay effect and optimizes cooling capacity's demand in an interval of every 10 min. The calculation formula of cooling capacity's demand in middle moment is as follows: (30) q sys , m i d d l e t = - ρ C P Q v { E ρ C P Q v + λ i λ o λ i + λ o T ¯ 0 - T i + λ i λ o λ i + λ o 2 + 2 π 144 2 τ 2 Δ T ¯ 0 sin 2 π 144 t - β 1 + C 1 λ i e - λ i + λ o t τ } 5) Cooling loads in different building functional areas: Large building's cooling areas, such as office areas, conference areas and other functional areas are different in the distribution of personnel and number of equipment units. In addition, there is a difference in time of room temperature's change during cooling and idle conditions at terminals of the air conditioning system. In order to supply cooling to terminals periodically, it is necessary to divide cooling area of the building into different functional groups. After that, each functional area can obtain periodic cooling separately according to its group. This method can reduce error of room temperature's change caused by the heat dissipation's difference of both personnel and equipment in different functional areas, and ensure that the room temperature in each functional area fluctuates within the specified range. T min n 3.2 The second stage: Optimal modeling of indoor cooling loads considering energy-saving and carbon-reduction 3.2.1 Objective function of the A/C system considering energy-saving and carbon-reduction On the basis of determining the optimal indoor cooling load requirement, the overall energy consumption of the A/C system needs to be further optimized. The overall operation optimization strategy of the A/C system is divided into two stages. Firstly, in the first stage, the hourly indoor cooling load's demand model is considered according to Eq. (17), and the optimal set indoor temperature at each moment is obtained based on the comfort and tariff weights. Then, the optimal indoor temperatures at each moment are taken as constraints and brought into the second stage of optimizing the operation of the A/C system's equipment. The overall optimization goal is to minimize the sum of energy's cost and carbon emission's cost. The objective function of the second stage optimization can be described as: (38) min C total = ∑ t ∈ T [ p ( t ) W total ( t ) + c ( t ) ε ( t ) W total ( t ) ] (39) W total ( t ) = W chiller ( t ) + W chwpump ( t ) + W cwpump ( t ) + W tfan ( t ) + W cfan ( t ) where C total indicates the total cost of the operational phase of the A/C system, p ( t ) indicates the price of electricity at t period, c ( t ) denotes the penalty cost of carbon emissions at t period, ε ( t ) indicates the dynamic carbon emission factor for each time period, W total ( t ) indicates the total energy consumption of the system at t period, W chiller ( t ) indicates the energy consumption of the chiller at t period, W chwpump ( t ) indicates the energy consumption of the chilled water pump at t period, W cwpump ( t ) indicates the energy consumption of the cooling water pump at t period, W tfan ( t ) indicates the energy consumption of the cooling tower fan at t period, W cfan ( t ) indicates the energy consumption of the fan coil in the indoor unit at t period. 3.2.2 Constraints of the A/C system considering energy-saving and carbon-reduction Fig. 2 visualizes the main constraints between A/C systems, from which the operational coupling as well as the constraints between devices within the A/C system can be seen. The constraints on the chilled water's supply temperature T chws and the cooling water's inlet temperature T cws can be expressed as: (40) T chws , m i n ≤ T chws ≤ T chws , m a x (41) T cws , m i n ≤ T cws ≤ T cws , m a x The network resistance needs to maintain a balance, the upper limit is determined according to the capacity of the pump engine. Constraints of the chilled water flow m chws and the cooling water flow m cws can be expressed as: (42) m chws , m i n ≤ m chws ≤ m chws , m a x (43) m cws , m i n ≤ m cws ≤ m cws , m a x The constraint of the cooling tower fan's airflow m tfan and the indoor fan's airflow m cfan can be expressed as: (44) m tfan , m i n ≤ m tfan ≤ m tfan , m a x (45) m cfan , m i n ≤ m cfan ≤ m cfan , m a x The chiller and the chilled water cycle's heat exchange process reflects the constraints between the chilled water pump and the chiller. According to the law of conservation of energy, the heat transfer's process is as follows: (46) Q chiller = m chw · c pw · T chwr - T chws where c pw indicates the specific heat capacity of water, T chwr indicates the chilled water's return temperature. According to the law of conservation of energy, the heat transfer process between the chiller and the cooling water cycle is as follows: (47) P chiller + Q chiller = m cws · c pw · T cwr - T cws where Q chiller indicates the actual cooling capacity of the chiller, c pw indicates the specific heat capacity of water, T cwr indicates return temperature of cooling water. The heat exchange between the cooling tower and the surrounding air in a cooling water system reflects the checks and balances between the cooling water pump and the cooling tower: (48) P chiller + Q chiller = 2.63 m w 1.11 1 + 1.12 m w m a 1.11 T cwr - T wb 3.3 Two-stage optimization solution process of the A/C system The purpose of the first stage optimization proposed in this paper is to obtain the indoor cooling load's demand that considers the electricity price and comfort demand. The indoor set temperature's reference value of the user in each time period is calculated by the demand optimization model established in Section 3.1. After that, based on the energy consumption model of the main energy consumption equipment established in Section 2.2 and the demand optimization constraints of each time period in the first stage, the A/C system is optimized for energy saving and carbon reduction in the second stage. Finally, the optimal operating conditions of the system are obtained at each moment, and the main solution process is shown in Fig. 3 . 4 Case study 4.1 Basic parameters and scenario settings This section selects a public building equipped with the A/C system to analyze the operation strategy. The example model is built on Python 3.8 and calls the solver Gurobi for Python to calculate the objective function. Basic parameter settings include: 1) Values of building parameter. Rooms in the same floor of an office building in Nanjing is taken as the research subject. The rooms are connected to each other. The total cooling area of the public building is 13238 m2, the building height is 41.9 m, and the ground floor is 11 layers. The thermal resistance of the roof is taken as 2.22 W/(m2·K), the density of internal personnel is taken as 36.27 m2/person, the lighting is 12.59 W/m2, and the heat dissipation of the equipment is 8.07 W/m2. The ventilation rate of the system is taken as 430 m3/h, the density of the air is 1.29 kg/m3, and the specific heat capacity is taken as 0.995 kJ/(kg·K). The thickness of the room wall is 240 mm, the density is 2600 kg/m3, and the heat transfer of the external wall to the outside is taken as 0.995 kJ/(kg·K). The thickness of the room wall is 240 mm, and the density is 2600 kg/m3. The heat transfer coefficient of the external wall is taken as 4.74 W/(m2∙K), the heat transfer coefficient of the wall and the interior is taken as 2.8 W/(m2∙K), and the total heat gain is taken as 3 kW. 2) Prediction of outdoor hourly temperature. Based on the assumptions about the meteorological parameters in Section 2, the outdoor temperature is considered as a sinusoidal fitting function. The fitted typical summer outdoor temperature profile can be obtained by bringing the historical meteorological data into Eq. (34), the result is shown in Fig. 4 . 3) Information on electricity prices. This paper adopts the time-sharing tariff standard for Nanjing enterprise users to calculate the energy cost of public buildings on a summer day. Assuming that the user's electricity consumption period is from 8:00 to 19:00, and the specific time periods and the corresponding tariff information are shown in Table 3 . 4.2 Results of energy consumption equipment parameter identification The A/C system in this paper uses two screw units with a rated cooling capacity of 650 kW and its rated power is 135 kW. Each unit includes a chilled water pump, a cooling water pump and a cooling tower. The value of forgetting factor in the recursive least squares iterative equation is 0.95. According to the recursive equation in section 2.3, the results of the energy model's parameter identification of the main equipment of the A/C system can be obtained as follow: 1) Parameters identification's results of the chiller's energy model are as follow: (49) θ PLRchiller k = 0.146 , 0.470 , 0.647 T (50) θ Temp k = 1.729 , 4.613 , - 1.875 , 12.545 , - 0.13 , 0.065 T 2) Parameter identification's results of the chilled water pump and the cooling water pump's energy consumption model are as follow: (51) θ chwpump = [ 1.492 , - 0.144 , 4.295 × 1 0 - 3 , - 1.567 × 1 0 - 5 ] T (52) θ cwpump = [ 1.09 , 7.722 × 1 0 - 2 , - 4.96 × 1 0 - 4 , 1.129 × 1 0 - 6 ] T 3) Parameter identification's results of the cooling tower fan's energy consumption model are as follow: (53) θ tfan = [ 0.861 , - 0.031 , 4.208 × 1 0 - 3 , - 2.372 × 1 0 - 5 ] T 4) Parameter identification's results of the fan's energy consumption model in the A/C system are as follow: (54) θ cfan = [ 0.808 , - 0.088 , 8.323 × 1 0 - 3 , - 9.823 × 1 0 - 5 ] T 4.3 Results of indoor load cooling optimization The corresponding thermal comfort values of each time period are shown in Table 4 . Table 4 presents the maximum PMV value as 0.472 and the minimum value as 0.227 in the optimal temperature setpoint environment. Both values are within the permissible range. The disparity in PMV subsequent to the modification of the temperature setpoint was contrasted with PMV at a consistent temperature setpoint of 26 °C. The optimal set value of temperature can reach up to 27.4℃ relative to the fixed value of 26℃ with an overall increase. By increasing the real time tariff incentive, the user's energy behavior has changed accordingly. After the cooling demand optimization, the temperature's setpoints for each time period are increased, which directly reduces the cooling demand of the room. The specified temperature is input into Eq. (31) to determine the cumulative cooling load in the indoor section of the A/C system at each instance, assuming a constant set value of 26 °C. The comparison results are depicted in Fig. 5 . From the changes in PMV during the optimization in Fig. 5, it can be seen that after the optimization of the indoor temperature's setpoints, the PMV increases relative to those before the adjustment, which decreases the user's human comfort, but the PMV values at each moment are within the allowed range mentioned in Section 3.1.1. The slight fluctuations in comfort levels noted from one hour to the next can be ascribed to the decrease in the requirement for indoor cooling, accomplished by modifying a segment of the human comfort requirement. It is important to note that although the tariff reaches its peak during 13:00–15:00. when outdoor temperatures are higher, the optimization strategy continues to prioritize improving human comfort by increasing the emphasis on thermal comfort for the users. This statement caters to the particular needs of users and also illustrates the benefits of considering the time lag characteristics of the A/C system. Also, the cooling load values exhibit a pattern of gradual increase followed by decrease when the temperature set value is constant. The cooling load peaks at approximately 12:00. There is a discernible disparity in the cooling load values between the two operational modes of fixed temperature set value and adjustable temperature set value. Properly adjusting the set temperature can effectively decrease the cooling load. The minimum reduction in cooling load is 81.02 kW at 8:00, representing approximately 7.26 % of the total load. At 12:00, the reduction in cooling load is 197.8 kW, representing approximately 15.52 % of the total load. Thus, through the examination of the correlation between variations in PMV when modifying the temperature setpoint, as depicted in Fig. 5, it becomes evident that the adoption of the temperature setpoint adjustment strategy has the potential to decrease the requirement for indoor cooling (Table 5 ). According to the result of the cooling load's demand obtained by the optimization, combined with the time lag correction strategy mentioned before, the operation process of the intermediate moment can be controlled. The impact of the time lag effect can be considered through the information of the human comfort and the change of time-sharing tariffs, so as to adjust the operation strategy of each part of the A/C system in the next moment. 4.4 Results of overall optimization This study selects 11 sets of consecutive working conditions within the operating hours of the A/C system on a typical summer day to conduct an energy-saving optimization analysis. Based on the findings of the cooling load demand derived from the optimization, in conjunction with the time lag correction strategy outlined in the preceding section, it is feasible to regulate the operational procedure during intermediate intervals. The time lag effect is considered by incorporating information on human comfort and changes in time-sharing tariffs to adapt the operational strategy of different components of the A/C system in the subsequent time period. A comparison of the energy consumption values following the aforementioned optimization and the energy consumption values resulting from operation at the rated conditions is depicted in Fig. 6 . Fig. 6 illustrates the substantial reduction in energy consumption generated by the A/C system in each time period following the optimization of its main operating parameters, as compared to the rated operating conditions. During the period from 11:00–14:00, the most significant decline in energy consumption is observed, reaching 58.62kWh, with an associated energy saving rate of 4.11 %. The decrease in energy consumption is minimal from 15:00–19:00, amounting to 13.42kWh, resulting in an energy saving rate of approximately 1.07 %. The cooling energy consumption per unit area of the A/C system under the rated working condition is 17.61 kWh/(m2·a), which is only between the limit value and the access value of the requirements for office buildings. After the two-stage operation optimization proposed in this paper, the cooling energy consumption per unit area of the A/C system under the optimal working condition is reduced to 6.96 kWh/(m2·a), the energy consumption for air conditioning refrigeration per unit area reduces 60.48 %, which is able to reach the advanced value mentioned in the standard, with a better energy-saving effect. The comparison charts between these optimized variables and original variables are shown in Figs. 7–9 : Considering the previously mentioned time lag effect, the A/C system is re-optimized at 10-minute intervals, and the outcomes of the optimization are illustrated in Fig. 10 . The figure demonstrates that the re-optimization during the intermediate time period leads to a further reduction in the energy consumption of the A/C system. By examining the area enclosed by the curve and the time axis, it is evident that there is a notable decrease in energy consumption from 8:00–11:00 and 17:00–19:00 The decrease in energy consumption during the midday hour is marginally lower, consistent with the earlier analysis of optimizing the demand for indoor cooling load. This is consistent with the results of the previous analysis of terminal cooling load's demand optimization. Due to the high outside temperature at noon, the temperature's difference between the two neighboring moments is small, the changes of the air conditioning unit's cooling capacity are relatively small. Even by adjusting the temperature of the chilled water pump, the cooling water pump and the compressor power, the reduction of energy consumption is also relatively limited. On the contrary, the A/C system's cooling capacity changes a lot when the outside world's temperature gradually increases or decreases in the moments of morning and evening. This is due to the consideration that the time lag would impact the next moment, controlling in an advanced time could generate a better energy-saving effect. Moreover, the A/C system has the potential to decrease the operational carbon emissions of the building while also conserving energy. As depicted in Fig. 11 , the carbon emissions of the A/C system exhibit varying degrees of reduction during the optimized time period. During the morning and evening periods, the carbon emissions from the A/C system decrease at a slower rate, leading to significant relative fluctuations attributed to the higher carbon emission factor. During the midday hours, when the carbon emission factor is lower, the carbon emissions from the A/C system decrease by a greater extent, and the reduction is relatively consistent. The dynamic carbon emission factors considered in the objective function are shown in Table 6 . 5 Conclusion This paper presents a two-stage operational optimization model for the indoor load of an A/C system. In the initial stage, a model for optimizing the demand of indoor cooling load is executed to determine the reference value for indoor set temperature during each time period. Subsequently, an optimization model aimed at energy conservation and carbon reduction is conducted based on the identification of key energy-consuming equipment parameters and optimal outcomes from the first stage, with the objective of minimizing the combined costs of energy consumption and carbon emissions. Case studies conducted during the summer have confirmed that: 1) Following the optimization of cooling load demand in the initial stage, there is a maximum reduction of 15.52 % in the cooling load. By implementing pre-cooling and increasing the demand for cooling during the typical time period, the optimization strategy enables the user to pre-store cold air in the room. Subsequently, the operation strategy for the various components of the A/C system can be adjusted in the following time period. 2) Optimization of the main operation parameters of the A/C system in the second stage has led to a maximum 4.11 % reduction in the system's energy consumption and 30.81 % reduction in the system's carbon emission compared to the rated operating conditions, consistently across all times. Furthermore, the energy consumption for air conditioning refrigeration per unit area reduces 60.48 %, and the carbon emissions from the A/C system are also decreased over the optimized time period. The impact of energy conservation and carbon reduction is highly significant. coredata.dc:description: The purpose of the air conditioning system (A/C system) is to meet the cooling capacity needs of individual rooms. In order to optimize energy-saving in the A/C system, it is essential to conduct a study on the operational status of various equipment, considering the comfort demand of the human body and dynamic electricity prices. This feature will enable collaborative control of the A/C system. Consequently, this paper presents a two-stage operational optimization strategy. Firstly, the comfort requirement is taken into consideration, and the room's set temperature is treated as a decision variable. An optimization strategy is proposed to meet real-time electricity prices and indoor cooling demand. Furthermore, by optimizing the cooling demand, the operation of the main equipment in the A/C system is also optimized, leading to the derivation of an optimal cooling strategy at the minute level. According to this strategy, there are significant reductions in the energy consumption and the carbon emission relative to the rated operating conditions at each time period. The energy consumption can be reduced by up to 4.11%, and the carbon emission can be reduced by up to 30.81%.
coredata.dc:title: Two-stage optimization for the air conditioning system in public buildings with flexible control of indoor load
